PR title: VideoCommon: Add shader logic ops support for Apple Silicon GPUs
PR body:
This PR adds a shader logic ops implementation for Apple Silicon GPUs. While Metal does not support logic ops itself, it *does* support framebuffer fetch, allowing us to implement it in the fragment shader. (Note that Intel, AMD, and NVIDIA GPUs do *not* support framebuffer fetch, so this PR will not solve the logic ops problem on Intel Macs.)

facebook/react-native
PR body:
This decouples non-UI logic from RCTDevMenu into a new module RCTDevSettings.
It also introduces the RCTDevSettingsDataSource protocol for storing dev tools preferences. This could allow a developer to implement alternative behaviors, e.g. loading the settings from some oth
commit messages:
Add RCTDevSettings module
RCTDevSettings provides all the interaction with the bridge and the rest of the app's runtime. RCTDevSettingsDataSource is the backing store for RCTDevSettings and is used to get/set values by RCTDevSettings. It should **not** alter values itself and try to update the devsettings (data flows only in one way). RCTDevMenu and our websocket (RCTDevConnection?) make use of RCTDevSettings: they get information from dev settings and write commands to it to alter state. Through that interface RCTDevSettings can decide to persist any settings using its RCTDevSettingsDataSource.

This is the next step in moving RN towards standard path-based requires. All the requires in `Libraries` have been rewritten to use relative requires with a few exceptions, namely, `vendor` and `Renderer/oss` since those need to be changed upstream. This commit uses relative requires instead of `react-native/...` so that if Facebook were to stop syncing out certain folders and therefore remove code from the react-native package, internal code at Facebook would not need to change.

The only option for upstream to add android support is by using the existing build system **and** glib as OSAL. If you want fluidsynth without glib on android, you have to use a custom fork. There is nothing further to review here, that's why I close this.

With general engineering CAD tools defined above, I don't think that commercial CAD software worth tens of thousands of dollars can be considered a toy because it doesn't have some unmaintained workbenches, each offering a single tool for a very specific purpose. Besides, nobody wants to remove those functionalities from FreeCAD. Just not show them by default since, let's face it, a very small percentage of users will ever need them. Or move them to another workbench so that functionality remains the same and FreeCAD is no dumber. This software has its quirk that the most important and useful tools are add-ons while the least useful ones are built-in. Fortunately, it's starting to change in current releases. We got rid of some redundant workbenches and tools that nobody used but they were included by default for some reason.
A code limitation shouldn't force itself on the UI imo. Is there no way for a module to load a general menu rather than be a separate workbench? Yes there might be more inspection tools later, I can see how a workbench would then make sense, but it is not the case and the workbench has been around for 12+ years. So what is the likelyhood that it will never happen?

> I don't understand what that additional check does (`max(self.move_d, prev_move.move_d) < 99999999.9 * cos_theta_d2`). At first glance though, it seems like that code would "round up" to higher junction speeds where I think we really want to "round down" in unusual corner cases like this.

is mostly right, however not entirely. The problem at hand is that as the segmentation for a curve becomes finer and finer, the angle between consecutive segments becomes closer and closer to 180 degrees (and cos(theta/2) approaches 0). And so, the current mainline Klipper code has an issue: it has a minimum limit for cos(theta/2), and thus technically produces incorrect results for angles theta very close to 180 degrees, both for consecutive straight segments and for very small segments forming a curve. Adjusting the limit  (e.g. setting it to -0.999999999999) just pushes the problematic cases further down the line. My approach is based on the following observation: for smooth curves, as the segmentation becomes finer, both move_d and cos(theta/2) go to 0, but their ratio does not (it does not go to either 0 or infinity), as limit(move_d / cos(theta/2)) = 2 * R. Thus, by checking the ratio move_d / cos(theta/2), we can tell apart the cases "a curve with finite curvature, just very fine"and "(sufficiently) straight segments" regardless of how fine the segmentation is, and without having to play with limits too much, and apply the junction velocity limits from centripetal acceleration only to the first case. You could still say that the code contains a threshold, but the behavior of the code does not depend on its value too much, basically if the threshold is sufficiently large, it won't matter how large exactly it is. This is not the case for junction_cos_theta, as for any threshold you could choose sufficiently small segmentation that would make code produce technically incorrect junction velocity limits.

PR body: The PR was not merged because the maintainer (thinkyhead) implemented an alternative solution that made the PR's approach obsolete. The maintainer explicitly stated 'Superseded by having G33 skip the probe result sanity check.' This indicates that rather than accepting the PR's workaround of allowing larger positional differences, the maintainer chose a different architectural approach that addressed the root cause more directly. Earlier comments show the maintainer considered the PR's solution 'a workaround that just happens to work for one situation and doesn't comprehend the real issue.' The discussion revealed that the real problem was that delta calibration (G33) needs to accept probe results outside normal ranges during calibration, which is better addressed by having G33 skip the sanity check entirely rather than adjusting tolerance values.

Yes, it already has a version number, and it should also have some flags indicating architecture and/or bytecode type.
And then the plan would be to use ".mpc" files to contain not only persistent bytecode, but also persistent native/viper code, inline assembler, as well as dynamic loadable C modules #583.  This might seem like trying to stuff a lot into one file, but it's actually quite natural, and means the user doesn't need to worry/know about all the different kinds of dynamically loadable content.
Agree it's ambitious, but I think we should try in this case!  It will be a good outcome if we get it right.  The whole project is anyway in a state of flux :)  We need to have the liberty to make changes, else we can't improve.

The modem sleep while connected to an AP is most likely a sleep between DTIMs from the AP, which usually come every 100ms (so sleep for about 95ms, wake for 5ms to turn on modem and receive).  So it would introduce a latency in reception of an Ethernet frame of up to 100ms.  You can try pinging the device while it's doing this DTIM sleep to see how it responds.
I also tried turning both AP and Station off. Ping fails, so it is going to sleep. But sometimes doing this results in a hard reset. Perhaps others can confirm/deny on reference hardware.

PR title: Autodesk: Fix bug where ResolveParameter doesn't support type conversion
PR body: Currently it is required that the type of the value must match the type of the parameter. However sometimes we still want to convert the value. For example, the Wrap parameter of the sampler requires a TfToken type, which can be TfToken(‚Äúrepeat‚Äù), TfToken(‚Äúclamp‚Äù) and so on. But in the USD file, it is common that we just write a string as the value. When we resolve the parameter, we need to cast from a string to token. This fix enables us to get the value from the usd file for the parameters, by

issue comments: The PR was not merged because it introduced performance regressions despite being titled as 'Minor DMA optimizations'. Testing by StevenMiller123 showed that the PR slightly reduces DMA performance compared to the main branch. Specifically, the atomic operation introduced for fault buffer marking caused a measurable performance degradation of around 2 frames per second when reverted. The PR author (raphaelthegreat) acknowledged that the atomic operation is 'technically necessary for sync but looks like its been fine without it', suggesting the optimization was unnecessary and actually harmful to performance. The maintainer (georgemoralis) expressed disappointment with the performance regression, commenting 'i thought the title was optimizations ;/'. While there were no graphical regressions, the performance degradation contradicts the PR's stated goal of optimization, making it unacceptable for merging.

PR title: The PR was not merged because it was superseded by an alternative implementation approach. The PR author (@thexai) explicitly closed this PR with the comment 'Closed in favor of https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/24183'. Another contributor (@CrystalP) had created PR #24183 which implemented a different approach using the database engine to do the work rather than the client-side caching approach proposed in this PR. The discussion in the comments shows that while this PR's approach was considered acceptable as a temporary fix, there was preference for a more architectural solution that would avoid the need for client-side caching altogether. The alternative PR (#24183) represented a different technical approach to solving the same performance issue.

PRÁºñÂè∑: The PR was not merged primarily due to project fit and release management concerns. Maintainer CrystalP raised several objections: 1) Timing - suggesting the upgrade should happen at the beginning of v23 for stability reasons rather than mid-cycle without pressing need; 2) Mirror usage - strongly objecting to disabling mirrors, explaining that Kodi's mirrors are essential for reproducible builds of older versions and prevent the project from being dependent on MSYS2's package retention policies; 3) Risk assessment - noting that new MSYS2 versions represent a change with potential risk, and operational changes shouldn't be made 'just because'. The maintainer explicitly stated they would let the Release Manager (RM) decide, indicating this is a release management decision rather than a technical issue. The technical implementation itself had minor review feedback but wasn't the blocking factor.
issue comments: Coordinate with release manager on appropriate timing for MSYS2 upgrades; Maintain mirror functionality while upgrading MSYS2; Address concerns about reproducible builds of older versions; Provide stronger justification for mid-cycle upgrade if needed
closed_reason: CrystalP: 'Why not upgrade msys, it's getting old after all. Timing it at the beginning of v23 would have been safer from a stability point of view, since there is no pressing need to upgrade. I'll let our RM decide.'; CrystalP: 'However I strongly object to disabling the usage of the mirrors, and the msys 20250622 + dependencies must be uploaded to the mirrors. They fix a 100% preventable problem.'; CrystalP: 'That's because msys removes older packages from their mirrors after some time that we don't control. That made v20 and v21 unbuildable (unless you have a personal copy of the packages somewhere ofc), and forced the late v21 upgrade, see #24133.'; CrystalP: 'The reason late v21 and v22 can still be built reliably is thanks to the mirrors. Without them core would be in the same broken situation as addons, that didn't have all the necessary packages uploaded to Kodi mirrors.'; CrystalP: 'New msys version = a change. Hopefully positive but there is a risk. In operations, things are not changed "just because" or "whenever".'
